summary: Behavioral economics shows that simple peer comparison letters and social norm nudges can safely and cost-effectively reduce inappropriate prescribing of medications like opioids and antipsychotics.

articles.title: Effect of Peer Comparison Letters for High-Volume Primary Care Prescribers of Quetiapine
articles.summary: A CMS randomized trial found that sending letters to high-prescribing doctors significantly reduced inappropriate prescribing of the antipsychotic quetiapine, without negative effects on patient health outcomes.

articles.title: Peer Comparison or Guideline-Based Feedback and Post-Surgery Opioid Prescribing
articles.summary: A randomized trial found that sending surgeons peer-comparison emails about their opioid prescribing volumes led to sharp reductions in opioid quantities prescribed after routine surgeries.

articles.title: Mailed Feedback to Primary Care Physicians on Antibiotic Prescribing
articles.summary: A BMJ randomized trial showed that sending antibiotic prescribing feedback letters to primary care physicians reduced prescribing by ~16%, demonstrating the power of low-cost nudges.

implementation_examples.title: NHS National Peer Comparison Letter Campaign

articles.title: Association between Electronic Medical Record Implementation of Default Opioid Prescription Quantities and Prescribing Behavior in Two Emergency Departments
articles.summary: This study found that setting a default prescription quantity of 10 opioid tablets in the EMR significantly increased the proportion of 10-tablet prescriptions from 21% to 43%, demonstrating that EMR defaults can safely reduce prescribing amounts.

implementation_examples.title: Default Setting in Electronic Medical Records 'Nudged' Emergency Department Physicians to Limit Opioid Prescriptions to 10 Tablets

articles.title: Behavioral Interventions to Reduce Inappropriate Antibiotic Prescribing
articles.summary: A randomized trial found that requiring justification in the EHR and sending peer comparison emails significantly reduced inappropriate antibiotic prescribing, while alternative treatment suggestions alone did not.
